generation

Class MazeFactoryTestEller

  • java.lang.Object
    • generation.MazeFactoryTest
      • generation.MazeFactoryTestEller

  • public class MazeFactoryTestEller
extends MazeFactoryTest

    MazeFactoryTestEller tests the validity of a maze generated by Eller's algorithm via MazeBuilderEller. It inherits black-box tests from MazeFactoryTest and supplements these by enabling white-box testing via in-line assertion statements inside MazeBuilderEller.

    JUnit params (org.junit.jupiter.params) is used to automate application of test cases to mazes of variable difficulty levels.

    Author:
    Elijah Mas

    • Method Detail

      • runAllTests

        @ParameterizedTest
 @ValueSource(ints={0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7})
public void runAllTests(int level)

        This method might be considered a stand-in "main" method for this class. It automates the execution of other methods that contain assert* statements but are not marked with the @Test annotation; the reason for doing this is that this method uses the @ParameterizedTest annotation, which allows all the other methods to be run with variable input arguments, which the plain @Test annotation does not permit. The parameter values (@ValueSource) are a series of integers that represent the different difficulty levels of puzzles involved that will be tested.

        Call hierarchy

        There are different levels of tests conducted. First, there are tests defined by the MazeFactoryTest and MazeFactoryTestEller classes:

        • allTests()
          • MazeFactoryTest.baselineTests()
            • MazeFactoryTest.testNoRoomsInPerfectMaze(): test that a perfect maze has no rooms.
            • MazeFactoryTest.testOneExitByBorders(): test that a maze has only one missing border around the periphery.
            • MazeFactoryTest.testExitAtExpectedLocation(): test that the exit location identified by a maze matches that which is detected by examining other maze properties.
            • MazeFactoryTest.testOneExitByDistance(): test that only one maze cell has a distance of 1 to the exit.
            • MazeFactoryTest.testMaxDistanceStartingPoint(): test that the starting point has the maximal distance to the exit of all cells in the maze.
            • MazeFactoryTest.testEveryCellHasExit() test that every cell has neighbors at distance=1 away and with no floorboards in between, which allows us to conclude that every cell in the maze can access the exit.
          • deterministicTest ensure that the seed of the random number generator is the same before each deterministic maze order.
          • testCells() Eller specific: test that all cells in the maze's set cells have value 1 when the algorithm concludes.
          • testCellSets() Eller specific: test that the set of cell sets has only one member when the algorithm concludes.


        This method additionally calls tests embedded in the MazeBulderEller class under assertion statements. There are two branches of tests in that class:

        • tests that run whenever VM -ea assertion is enabled
        • tests that run when VM -ea assertion is enabled && MazeBuilderEller.ENABLE_TESTS=true.

        Each one of these tests is run at the specified difficulty levels (currently 0-7); at each difficulty level we run all the above tests for four cases, save for MazeFactoryTest.testNoRoomsInPerfectMaze():

        1. a perfect maze
        2. an imperfect maze where rooms are handled dynamically by Eller's algorithm
        3. a perfect maze (again)
        4. an imperfect maze where rooms are ignored by Eller's algorithm until it has iterated through all rows, at which point rooms are retroactively opened up
        As implied by the name, MazeFactoryTest.testNoRoomsInPerfectMaze() is run only for a perfect maze.


        Test 3 is redundant from test 1, but undoing that redundancy is more effort at the moment than worthwhile. Tests 2 and 4 check an important distinction. Test 2 reflects the operation of the normal Maze application: rooms are handled at each row as the algorithm progresses, and their walls are randomly opened. There is a small but nonzero chance that, because randomization is involved, a room will stand completely unopened after Eller's algorithm iterates over it. This is a corner case that must be handled. Test 4 forces this corner case to occur in a testing environment, to make sure that in the unlikely event it occurs in client-side use, it will be handled correctly.

        Overrides:
        runAllTests in class MazeFactoryTest
        Parameters:
        level - the difficulty level of the maze

      • testCells

        public void testCells()
        Tests that all maze cells belong to a single set by checking the array holding set values. Calls _testCells(MazeBuilderEller).

      • _testCells

        public boolean _testCells(MazeBuilderEller builder)
        Checks that all cells in the maze belong to the set with id=1, as prescribed by this implementation of Eller's algorithm. If any cell is found with any other value, return false. ***Expected result: all cells contain 1.
        Parameters:
        builder - a MazeBuilderEller Instance
        Returns:
        boolean that is true if the test is successful.

      • testCellSets

        public void testCellSets()
        Tests that all maze cells belong to a single set by checking the array holding set values. Calls _testCellSets(MazeBuilderEller).

      • _testCellSets

        public boolean _testCellSets(MazeBuilderEller builder)
        Checks that there is only one set of cells identified in the maze, that the id of this set is 1, and that all cells in the maze are contained in this set.
        Parameters:
        builder - a MazeBuilderEller instance
        Returns:
        boolean that confirms the check
